Submodules¶

mfm.math.signal module¶

mfm.math.signal.autocorr(x: 'np.array', axis: 'int' = 0, fast: 'bool' = False, normalize: 'bool' = True) → 'np.array'[source]¶

Estimate the autocorrelation function of a time series using the FFT.

Parameters

  • x – The time series. If multidimensional, set the time axis using the axis keyword argument and the function will be computed for every other axis.

  • axis – (optional) The time axis of x. Assumed to be the first axis if not specified.

  • fast – (optional) If True, only use the largest 2^n entries for efficiency. (default: False)

mfm.math.signal.get_fwhm(curve: 'mfm.curve.Curve', **kwargs) → 'Tuple[float, Tuple[int, int], Tuple[float, float]]'[source]¶

Calculates the FWHM using a linear-search from both sides of the curve

Parameters

curve –

Returns

a tupel containing the FWHM and the indices and the x-values of the used positions

mfm.math.signal.window(data: 'np.array', window_len: 'int', window_function_type: 'str' = 'bartlett') → 'np.array'[source]¶

smooth the data using a window with requested size.

This method is based on the convolution of a scaled window with the signal. The signal is prepared by introducing reflected copies of the signal (with the window size) in both ends so that transient parts are minimized in the begining and end part of the output signal.

see also:

numpy.hanning, numpy.hamming, numpy.bartlett, numpy.blackman, numpy.convolve scipy.signal.lfilter

Parameters

  • data – 1D numpy-array (data)

  • window_len – the dimension of the smoothing window; should be an odd integer

  • window_function_type – the type of window from ‘flat’, ‘hanning’, ‘hamming’, ‘bartlett’, ‘blackman’ flat window will produce a moving average smoothing.

Returns

1D numpy-array (smoothed data)
